column22: Majority of clients of mine are coming from an already existing caloric deficit. Typically in their first assesment logs or interviews they are already eating less than 1,000 calories. Therefore majority of all of them start in some progression of reverse dieting back into overal general caloric intake. Then the second step of my program is adjusting macros and activities, step 3 food timing , step 4 progressions/adjustments or maintenance. In my programs and practice the first 6 weeks of them reverse dieting has achieved great fat loss while preserving if not improving lean mass. I use InBody machines for these measures.

column15: I would add an extra 70-75 calories per day the first week of a reverse diet, following a fatloss phase.   220lbs male (100kg), Their new predicted TDEE would be approx. 3080 - 3520 depending on activity levels. I will take the lower range to be safe and minimize fat gain. To account for metabolic adaptation multiply by 90%. New predicted maintenance calories approx. 2772 calories with a goal of getting there within 3-4 weeks post fat loss phase.   2000 calories is low for 220lbs male, so my initial first week increase would be more aggressive at 25% increase of total calories (an extra 500 calories). So approx. 70-75 calories per day increase the first 7 days.
column17: Out of the 70-75 calories per day, I would do 0g protein increase, 15-16g carbs increase, 1-2 g fat increase per day for the first 7 days.   For a 220lbs male at 2000 calories. Ideally his protein is 1g/lbs considering he is in a fatloss phase. However that would be really difficult, since we do not know his goal weight to determine the protein, let‚Äôs take 0.8g/lbs which is 176g protein per day (704 calories). Fats minimum requirement is 0.25grams/lbs so 55grams of fat (495), the rest made up of carbs 200 grams (801 calories).   His protein is in a good place, so we would just be increasing his fats and carbs. Focus would be primarily carbs, and secondary fats.
column18: Per day, assuming protein was already 1g/lbs bodyweight. 0g protein increase, 1.7g fat increase, 7g carb increase per day the first 7 days.   132 lbs female. Predicted TDEE between 1848 - 2112 calories. Take the lower end since I do not know activity level. Multiply by 90% to account for metabolic adaptation - 1663 new predicted maintenance.  First week would add in 30% of her current calories (additional 300 calories). More aggressive since this is very low for a female. Assuming at the end of the fatloss phase, protein was at least 0.8-1.0 grams/lbs of bodyweight = 105.6 - 132 grams of protein. I will assume the higher end at 132 grams/lbs (considering she was in a fatloss phase and needed to maintain muscle).  132g Protein (528 calories) 33g fat (minimum 0.25 x lbs of bodyweight) (297 calories) 44g carbs (175 calories - filled in the rest after P and F were accounted for).   Protein is good so the focus is carbs and fats. Female generally need more hormonal fats so would be more aggressive with those than a male, 12 grams fat total, 48 grams carbs total.
column21: Yes.   Specifically, physique competitors after prolong calorie restriction and incredibly low body fat levels. Due to the down regulation of several important hormones (such as thyroid, leptin, insulin, testosterone) and the increase of ghrelin, and cortisol, that are involved in hunger cues, and satiety, they often find that it‚Äôs challenging to stay within the reverse diet calories, as their hunger has been severely elevated. This can cause an over consumption of calories, and therefore significant body fat levels increasing very quickly.
column22: It depends on the client, however, it‚Äôs important to be able to balance your hormones again after severe fat loss phase. Staying in an extreme calorie deficit can have several negative side effects on your hormones, such as your thyroid, your metabolism, sex hormones, energy levels, mood, sleep, etc.. the goal is always to be able to get your calories back up to maintenance calories (and hopefully surpass predictive maintenance levels), while maintaining healthy body fat levels.

column17: Protein would have been set to optimal in the fat-loss phase. Therefore, The primary focus in the initial bump would primarily be CHO, with a secondary focus on fats. Trace protein would also increase based on the carb sources. (IE: Jasmine rice) Therefore, the true macro increase would probably be 70g CHO, 15g Pro, 9g Fats.
column18: Normally, I would start with an approx 20% calorie increase, however in this particular approx  example I would be more aggressive and add a minimum of 30% or 300kcal perhaps even higher and more of a "Recovery Diet" depending on labs if avail./subjective biofeedback. Rational : 1,000 calories is very low and I am making the assumption that this client would be experiencing significant metabolic adaptations, hormonal imbalances and reporting poor subjective biofeedback markers. I would prescribe approx 40g of CHO (a little over 50% of kcal increase) approx 13g of fats (40% of kcal increase) and 5g of protein from trace sources found in CHO (10% of kcal increase.) Note: The increased ratio of fats in the case is for sex hormone function. Also, If the diet ended at 1,500 calories I would use a slightly less aggressive increase in calories, probably 20% instead of 30%.
column21: The results are almost always positive in terms of hormonal factors, strength, sleep quality, energy, recovery, motivation to train, libido. However, adherence has been an issue with some clients where they have a difficult time adhering to new increased calorie targets, even if they are significant. This is more prominent when the client is in a fat-loss phase for a major event or milestone like wedding, tropical vacation etc. They no longer have the overarching goal to focus on and therefore commitment levels are not as strong.
column22: My objective is always to achieve sustainable results. We know that dieting works in the short term, but long-term fat-loss statistics are grim. I educate my clients on the weight loss/weight regain statistics and the metabolic and hormonal adaptations that occur in the fat-loss phase. Our goal is to reverse those adaptations and improve subjective biofeedback so they feel better and can enjoy a larger calorie budget and a more flexible lifestyle.  A reverse diet over 3-6 weeks is a more conservative approach of increasing calories that many clients feel more comfortable with psychologically compared to going directly to theoretical maintenance or into a calorie surplus. They‚Äôve worked hard to obtain a lean physique and the reverse diet approach often maintains a lean body composition and because metabolic adaptation works in both directions, we can usually increase their maintenance calories beyond what they were at the start of a fat-loss phase if we titrate the calories upwards incrementally.

column15: I would increase calories mainly coming from carbohydrates (to help with cortisol levels and Leptin/Ghrelin, and energy). I would increase calories over a period of 3-8 weeks working our way up to maintenance as quickly as possible while ensuring the weight stays within 5lbs of his new low body weight. Since this client is on a very low end of calories I would do a 15-20% increase. I would add an addition 300-350 calories the first seven days mainly coming from carbohydrates during the first week of his reverse.
column17: For this client, his protein intake should already be around 1 gram per pound of body weight so, I would keep his protein intake the same (220g of protein 880 calories), I would have probably had his fats at 25% of his caloric intake (500 calories and 55G), with the remainder coming from carbs (620 calories and 155g carbs) for a 2000 caloric deficit. For his increase, I would initially add an extra 300 calories bumping up mainly carbs - total calories 2,300 for the first week - 220g P 880 calories, I would bump carbs up to 220g daily 880 calories, and bump fats to ,60g 540 calories
column18: This is an extreme deficit so I may take a more vigorous approach adding in 40% more calories to put this client at 1,400 calories for the first week of her reverse.
column19: I typically spend 3 to 8 weeks with my clients in a reverse diet depending on the extremities of their fat loss.
column21: I've only ever seen positive changes in a reverse diet with my clients - typically energy levels go up, hunger hormones become more stabilized, sleep imrpoves, and strength and workout performance improves. The only time I've seen negative effects is when they client has not been consistent in a reverse.
column22: The only time I havent implement a reverse diet is when a client has not yet reached their fat loss goals but has been dieting for extended periods of time. This is where I would implement a 1 to 2 week diet break. Reverse dieting is crucial to ensure the client keeps the weight off long term after they've achieved their fat loss goals.

column21: adherence can be difficult
column22: to restore metabolism, mitigate metabolic adaptation, boost metabolic capacity, improve biofeedback (sleep, energy, etc)

column21: sometimes lack of adherence which would make them gain body fat faster.
column22: to prevent rapid fat gain and matabolic adaptations. After a period of caloric deficits, hormones related to hunger and satiety might be affected, metabolism might slow down. Reverse diet will allow metabolism to adjust and promote a more sustainable transition to maintnance. Reverse diet minimizes the risk of significant fat accumulation while giving the metabolism time to adapt. This approach will help maintain the hard earned fat loss and avoid the pit-falls of returning to old habits. Its for long term weight maintenance.

column22: For small calorie deficits, I don‚Äôt. I may continue coaching clients while they‚Äôre at maintenance calories if they ask. I only implement a reverse diet if the calorie deficit is greater than 20%

column15: If stage lean probably 600-800, if at a sustainable body composition 300-400ish, if struggling with consistency at the end of prep possibly more in the interest of consistency
column17: If increasing 500-800 cal for someone stage lean probably 100g or more increase in carbs, 10g or more increasee in fat and minimal protein changes
column18: If stage lean and bumping around 500-600 cal probably close to 100g carbs and 10ish grams fat with minimal protein changes
column19: My goal is to get them feeling better coming off a show within 6-8 weeks but I would keep pushing food through their entire offseason as much as possible while staying at a reasonable offseason body composition
column21: If adherance is low coming off a show I typically push food faster in the interest of consistency. Staying consistent with higher food usually results in less rapid gain than aiming for low targets and being inconsistent.
column22: I think there needs to be a middle ground. Gaining everything back quickly isnt ideal but gaining nothing back isnt ideal either. I like to see a 1-2lb gain the first 6-8 weeks coming off of a show to get them feeling better then slow things down from there.

column22: makes the transition smoother, easier on digestion, helpful with maintaining routine and habits set

column15: ~ 30 kcal per day

Depends on length of deficit, how much weight was lost, biofeedback of the client and how 2000 calories compares to his estimated TDEE. Generally, I would bump at least 50% up between the 2k calories and estimated TDEE to start.
column17: No protein since it should be in a sufficient place still. Typically a higher % carb increase than fats but would increase both initially - about 60-70% carbs and 30-40% fats to fill the added calories.
column18: Same as above: No protein since it should be in a sufficient place still. Typically a higher % carb increase than fats but would increase both initially - about 60-70% carbs and 30-40% fats to fill the added calories.
column21: Adherence can suffer since adding food can be daunting for certain clients who are afraid to gain body fat back. I will take a slightly slower approach with adding food and ensure I'm educating them on the importance of getting back to a maintenance intake.
column22: Taking a more gradual approach compared to a recovery diet tends to support adherence better for gen pop clients. It's rare for a gen pop client to get so lean that they would require a recovery diet or need to gain body fat back after a deficit.

column19: between 4-8 weeks depending on compliance and progress
column21: The psychological effect has been the biggest obstacles. When my client lose weight and get to the goal, they get nervous to increase their calories because they believe they will gain all their weight back. This is when coaching needs to be very supportive and once you build trust with your client it helps. Bloating does occur at times so I will adjust their meal plan to incorporate more foods to reduces bloating.
column22: It helps prevent your metabolism from slowing down, which often happens during calorie restriction. By gradually increasing calories, you signal to your body that it's not in a prolonged scarcity mode.  Also, it helps in maintaining your muscle mass. Rapidly jumping back to your pre-diet calorie levels can lead to muscle loss. Slowly adding calories gives your body the resources it needs for recovery and growth.  Lastly, it's a sustainable approach. Quick fixes may give short-term results, but they're rarely maintainable. Reversing diet allows for a smoother transition, making it more likely for your clients to stick with their healthier habits for the long haul.

column15: I would take him to 2400-2600 per day for the first week.
column17: This depends on what previous ‚Äúmaintenance‚Äù macros were.. for instance, if client was on a higher carb percentage, I would not take him to a lower carb percent. Each client‚Äôs macro ratios are custom to them and their tolerance in prep and post show.
column18: Same answer and previous. Both for male and female.
column19: Until we reach maintenance. There is no stock answer here. Some will reach maintenance quickly. Some require more free meals mentally than others.
column21: The only negative affects come when a client doesn‚Äôt adhere to the reverse. If a client has been in prep for a long time very restricted, they will tend to not adhere. Binging and rapid fat loss can severely mess with hormones and overall mental health.
column22: Because it allows the body to adjust at an appropriate pace‚Ä¶ physically and hormonally.

Returning to a maintenance phase of sorts while reverse dieting, as ive seen, has allowed their body to adjust and adapt to the new body fat levels without massive gain.
